title: The rise of the Ottoman Empire - Mostafa Minawi

multiple-choice.question: Who established the small principality in what is now Turkey that eventually became the vast Ottoman Empire?

options.label: A
options.text: Strategic alliances and military conflicts with neighboring principalities

options.label: C
options.text: Cultural innovation and unique blend of cultural influences

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the fierce military elite force that the Ottomans created using captured and converted young Christian boys?
What was the name of the city that the Ottomans conquered in 1453, which became the Ottoman capital?
Who was the Ottoman Sultan who prepared for the attack on Constantinople by hiring a Hungarian engineer to forge the largest cannon in the world?
What was the name of the tax that non-Muslims had to pay in exchange for religious freedom under Ottoman rule?
What was the name of the famous architect who filled the city of Istanbul with splendid mosques and other buildings commissioned by the sultans?
What was the name of the ceramics that were made using techniques from China's Ming dynasty, reimagined with Ottoman motifs?
How long did the Ottoman Empire last?
What was the extent of the Ottoman Empire at its peak?

options.label: A
options.text: From Hungary to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa to the Crimean Peninsula

options.label: B
options.text: From Turkey to the Middle East

title: Do personality tests work? - Merve Emre

multiple-choice.question: What is the main criticism of the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) and other personality tests?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too simple and don't provide enough information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are based on self-reported answers and have design flaws that make them unreliable.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for individual self-discovery and not for institutional decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the design flaws of personality tests that can lead to biased responses?

options.label: A
options.text: They are based on objective facts and data.

options.label: B
options.text: They are self-reported and people may lie or provide answers they think the test administrator wants to hear.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used for forced-choice questions and don't allow for open-ended answers.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for individual self-discovery and not for institutional decisions.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is shy and timid.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who finds alone time restorative.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the consequences of using personality tests in institutions, such as schools and companies?

options.label: A
options.text: People are more likely to excel in their chosen field.

options.label: B
options.text: People are less likely to be deprived of opportunities they would excel at.

options.label: C
options.text: People are more likely to be discouraged from considering certain paths.

options.label: D
options.text: People are less likely to be advised on what to study or pursue.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of personality tests?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too simple and don't provide enough information.

options.label: C
options.text: They are based on self-reported answers and have design flaws that make them unreliable.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for individual self-discovery and not for institutional decisions.

options.label: C

options.label: A
options.text: They are based on objective facts and data.

options.label: B
options.text: They are self-reported and people may lie or provide answers they think the test administrator wants to hear.

options.label: C
options.text: They often use forced-choice questions, which can lead to inconsistent results.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only used for individual self-discovery and not for institutional decisions.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the consequences of using personality tests being used in institutions?

options.label: A
options.text: People are more likely to excel in their chosen field.

options.label: B
options.text: People are less likely to be deprived of opportunities they would excel at.

options.label: C
options.text: People are more likely to be discouraged from considering certain paths.

options.label: D
options.text: People are less likely to be advised on what to study or pursue.

options.label: A
options.text: They are too complex and difficult to understand.

options.label: B
options.text: They are too simple and don't provide enough information.

options.label: C

title: 10 ways to have a better conversation - Celeste Headlee

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the speaker's presentation?

options.label: B
options.text: The need to balance talking and listening in conversations.

options.label: C
options.text: The role of technology in disrupting conversations.

options.text: The importance of being present and focused in conversations.

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: They are not affected by the study.

multiple-choice.question: What is the first rule for having better conversations?

options.label: B
options.text: Use open-ended questions to encourage meaningful responses.

options.label: C
options.text: Don't multitask and be present in the moment.

options.label: D
options.text: Listen actively and try to understand the other person's perspective.

multiple-choice.question: What is the importance of listening in conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows us to talk more and interrupt others.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows us to focus on our own thoughts and opinions.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows us to understand the other person's perspective and build stronger connections.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not important in conversations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the 10th rule for having better conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: Be brief and interested in other people.

options.label: B
options.text: Listen actively and try to understand the other person's perspective.

options.label: C
options.text: Use open-ended questions to encourage meaningful responses.

options.label: D
options.text: Don't repeat yourself and avoid being condescending.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main reason why we don't listen to each other?

options.label: A
options.text: We are too busy talking and want to be the center of attention.

options.label: B
options.text: We are distracted and our minds are filling in other thoughts.

options.label: C
options.text: We are not interested in the other person's perspective.

options.label: D
options.text: We are not able to listen and understand the other person's perspective.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice for having better conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: To be brief and interested in other people.

options.label: B
options.text: To listen actively and try to understand the other person's perspective.

options.label: C
options.text: To use open-ended questions to encourage meaningful responses.

options.label: C

options.text: Struggling to link objects to the correct context.

options.label: C
options.text: The influence of current opinions and experiences on past memories.

options.label: D
options.text: The incorporation of information from outside sources into personal recollections without realizing it.

options.text: Participants struggled to link the objects to the correct context.

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: A study where participants who said they had no recollection of their past opinions on marijuana legalization.

options.label: C
options.text: A study where participants who said they had been against marijuana legalization in 1973 but reported being for it in 1982 were more likely to recall that they were actually for legalization in 1973.

options.label: D
options.text: A study where participants had no recollection of their past opinions on marijuana legalization.

options.label: B
options.text: The group that did not know how the war ended rated the winning side as more likely to win than the group who did.

options.label: C
options.text: Both groups rated the winning side as equally likely to win.

options.label: D
options.text: Neither group rated the winning side as likely to win.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how fallibilities of memory can have real-world impacts?

options.label: A
options.text: Incorrect identifications or unreliable confessions in police interrogations.

options.label: A

options.label: D
options.text: Our memories are reliable representations of reality.

options.label: B
options.text: It can lead to inaccurate diagnoses.

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to incorrect identifications or unreliable confessions.

options.label: D
options.text: It can lead to biased conclusions.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: It can lead to accurate eyewitness testimony.

options.label: D

title: Why people fall for misinformation - Joseph Isaac

multiple-choice.question: What was the main contribution of David H√§nig's dissertation to the field of taste research?

options.label: D
options.text: He debated the existence of tastes like fatty, alkaline, metallic, and water-like.

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: They were used to debate the existence of tastes like fatty, alkaline, metallic, and water-like.

multiple-choice.question: What contributed to the widespread acceptance of the tongue map?

options.label: C
options.text: The debate over other tastes like fatty, alkaline, metallic, and water-like.

multiple-choice.question: What complicates the tongue map and highlights the need for skepticism?

options.label: B

options.label: B
options.text: It highlights the need for skepticism when encountering convenient charts or surprising anecdotes.

options.label: C
options.text: It complicates the understanding of taste and highlights the need for further research.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a widely accepted concept that has been perpetuated through a series of distortions.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The tongue map is a concept that was introduced before the discovery of umami.

options.label: C
options.text: The tongue map is a concept that was introduced after the discovery of umami.

options.label: D
options.text: The tongue map and umami are unrelated concepts.

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the need for further research in the field of taste.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a clear and easy-to-understand explanation of how we experience taste.

options.label: D
